Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Molecular mechanisms underlying rapid adaptive divergence in the Swamp Sparrow
Award.AbstractNarration:
Populations of a single species that live in different geographic regions often diverge as natural selection drives adaptation to the local environment. Understanding the processes of divergence and local adaptation is of particular importance in this contemporary era of rapidly changing environments. The coastal salt marshes of North America provide excellent systems in which to study rapid adaptive divergence, given that these habitats have formed within the last 15,000 years and represent novel selective environments for their inhabitants. Within many independent lineages of birds, there is a strong pattern of evolving larger bills and darker plumage after colonizing coastal salt marshes, suggesting that these traits offer a selective advantage. This project will allow identification of the genetic basis of divergence in these traits, and provide a window into the evolutionary mechanisms underlying local adaptation. This project will also provide hands-on training for graduate and undergraduate students, and will provide useful information for the conservation of coastal bird populations.

Two locally adapted subspecies of the Swamp Sparrow exist in the northeastern US: A brown inland form with a small bill, and a dark grey coastal form with a large bill. Preliminary DNA sequence (ddRAD) data reveal that the two forms are very similar, but several regions of the genome are highly differentiated between them. The natural history of coastal Swamp Sparrows suggests that strong directional selection may have influenced sequence variation in these highly differentiated regions. To test this hypothesis, patterns of genome-wide divergence will be surveyed by generating additional DNA sequence data for each differentiated region; these will be statistically examined for molecular signatures of selective sweeps. This project provides an important test of this emerging statistical methodology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Animals that live in places where their environment changes dramatically provide the opportunity to study whether they become tightly adapted to these changing conditions over time. Inland and coastal populations of the North American swamp sparrow are appropriate subjects for this kind of research because these birds remain similar in many ways, yet they live in two very different habitats: coastal salt marshes and inland freshwater marshes. The salt marsh habitat is particularly harsh for sparrows, since the birds there must handle higher amounts of salt in their diet, nest in areas that are regularly flooded by high tides, and deal with much higher temperature fluctuations. Past studies have shown that these two kinds of sparrows are indeed each adapted to their respective environments in many ways, but the genetic aspects of this story remained almost completely unknown. Using advanced genome comparison technology, we found reduced genetic variation in the salt marsh birds, showing that these populations have consistently been smaller than the freshwater populations, both now and in the past. We further identified 31 particular genes that differ strikingly between salt marsh and freshwater marsh sparrows. More importantly, most of these genes have connections to traits known to be important in the local adaptation of these sparrows, including genes for bill shape, plumage darkness, and salt tolerance. Some of these genes influence more than one kind of trait, raising the possibility that, for example, the salt marsh sparrows are darker not because being dark is beneficial in the salt marsh habitat, but rather as a by-product of selection on a gene for salt tolerance that also happens to cause sparrow feathers to be more black. These findings have general importance for our understanding of how animals become adapted to their environments, and for how this changes over time as their habitats change. It has specific relevance to the conservation of these sparrows, as their salt marsh habitat has declined greatly in extent and the salt marsh sparrows are now rare. Outcomes from this study have been broadly used as examples in classroom teaching and in lectures for the general public.
